Can anyone explain to me how the protocol incentivizes the topping up of collateral? For example, let's say I short COMP through minting synthetics at a high collateralization ratio. Then over several days COMP goes up in price. I'm still collateralized but it seems like COMP will continue to go up. What incentive do I have to fix my ratio vs. just cutting my losses and letting my position get liquidated?
Will need to know a little more about what you are trying to build. Theoretically any financial product could use UMA - tricks are in the details though
This is a very cool idea. Best way I can think of to do this is to monitor the contracts UMA has running.

I am not too sure this is meant to be a protocol incentive, it seems financial to me. Either you want to keep your position or you want to get liquidated. That choice, as far as I can tell, is up to the user. Is there a specific reason why you are asking about this?

Yes, we're concerned about making a synthetic that is extremely volatile. 

If there is no incentive to increase collateral and the starting collateralization ratio is too low, wouldn't the probability of the synthetic breaking be quite high? I.E. at expiration of the synthetic token there would be no way to redeem it for its full value. This would be a bad experience for the buyers.

One way to fix this would be to require a very high initial collateralization ratio but we're afraid that would be a bad experience for the sellers. Would people really be interested in minting a volatile synth if the ratio was 3X or 5X?

We're not sure how to reconcile this for the buyers and sellers (seller = someone who mints, not who buys and sells on a secondary market). 

One thought was to have a way to incentivize adding collateral to avoid liquidation. 

Do you have any examples of users or people on your team calculating the trade-off of allowing their collateral to be liquidated vs. hypothetical losses incurred for different ranges of price movements (e.g. 100%, 200%, 300%)??
So the incentive we're interested in understanding is definitely economic and set by us but facilitated by how you set up your protocol (i.e. liquidation).

üëã Hey all, still hacking on UMA, building a CFD platform. Kind of stuck figuring out a central logistic of the platform:

Option A) Have a few premade contracts that track prices of major Ethereum tokens/indexes like Ether, Chainlink, Uniswap Token, etc. The user can still set parameters such as strike and expiry when opening a CFD.

Option B) Have a system in which users create their own contracts on-demand from scratch and enter their own token addresses. This would allow anyone to trade CFDs for ANY Ethereum security token.

Basically, your incentive is that your collateral becomes liquidatable while it is still more valuable than the synthetic. Let's say the cutoff point is 1.25 collateralization. You become liquidatable when your collateral reaches 1.24, so the liquidator has an incentive to pay back your debt (in the synthetic) and take all of your collateral, and you're incentivized to top it off.

If the price crashes fast enough that you're actually *undercapitalized*, below 1.00, then there's no incentive to liquidate a position or to top off collateral. For extremely volatile collateral, the safe collateralization ratio would be higher than for less volatile collateral, and can be set in the contract configuration.

Hey UMAns. My teammate <@!430504266633838602>  and I are interested in building an oracle to track the volatility of the APYs of popular pools/vaults. They have variable APYs but we're interested in just _how_ variable they are over time.

If we are successful in this endeavor, we'd like to be able to make bets on the volatility. Am I correct in understanding we could use UMA to mint a token that tracks our oracle? Or is this a synthetix use case?

You can create a price identifier (or several price identifiers) that track APY volatility and use that with UMA's oracle to mint synthetics. This sounds pretty similar to the ethVIX identifier, which tracks ETH volatility. In the ethVIX case, the development team provides the VIX values via an API, but with a fallback to calculating with raw data. In your case, since the raw data comes from on-chain, you may not need to make a centralized API available, except for your own convenience. You could write a price feed interface that gets the on-chain values and runs the calculations, so anybody could use that for bots watching positions. https://github.com/UMAprotocol/UMIPs/blob/master/UMIPs/umip-74.md

Also, this is a great use case for UMA, since APY volatility is a fairly specialized data feed, and you would need Chainlink nodes delivering these specific prices on-chain repeatedly to do this with Synthetix. That's pretty expensive for long-tail synthetics like these. With UMA, you only have to get a prices on-chain at expiry or when there is a dispute about a liquidation or withdrawal.

If you make all price requests through the LSP itself and set the custom liveness internally in the function, that will make sure that all price requests recognized as valid by the LSP will follow the custom liveness rules for that particular product. <@726966670211678378>: part of our philosophy in building our oracle is that the data provided should be truly decentralized / without a point of trust. For this reason, I am personally skeptically of trusting API data directly since APIs are controlled by centralized parties (aka the endpoint publishing the API data can report any value they want).

But if your API data is "verifiable", this is solved. For example, if your question is "the price of XYZ is 123" (and XYZ is publicly knowable), then you can do the following.

1. Have an off-chain bot query your API to get the price of XYZ.
2. Have the off-chain bot "propose" the price of XYZ on-chain by making the following statement:

```
bytes ancillaryData = bytes("Q:The price of XYZ is $123? A:1 for yes. 0 for no.");
// fill in a couple other parameters; see the quick start guide on the docs site
oo.requestPrice(identifier, requestTime, ancillaryData, bondCurrency, reward); // request price
oo.setCustomLiveness(identifier, requestTime, ancillaryData, 30); // set 30 sec challenge period
// now we propose the value of "1" proposing that "Yes! The price of XYZ is $123". 
oo.proposePriceFor(msg.sender, address(this), priceIdentifier, timestamp, ancillaryData, int256(1e18);
```
3. After the challenge period (which we set to 30 sec‚Äîthis is a parameter you can change depending on your security needs), we can query to see if the proposed answer was undisputed, and therefore accepted as true.

```
oo.settle(address(this), identifier, requestTime, ancillaryData);
oo.getRequest(address(this), identifier, requestTime, ancillaryData).resolvedPrice;
```

And just to follow up on that, a typical challenge period is two hours, but there are a couple of approaches to speed up execution.

One is to shorten the challenge period, if you know there is an active disputer network that will spot and challenge any bad proposals immediately. That might be doable for an API value but you have to consider the risks.

Another approach is to have someone post a large bond to "insure" the value, which will be slashed if the value turns out to be incorrect, to compensate the affected parties. That would allow you to use the proposed value immediately, while the longer challenge window is available to challenge the value, slash the proposer, and compensate whoever was harmed (probably by taking the slashed bond for the protocol and redistributing in some way).
